fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Documents on blood risk were pulped, Owen says Government documents relating to imported blood which exposed thousands to HIV and hepatitis C were "selectively" destroyed, the former Labour health minister Lord Owen told a public inquiry yesterday. He called for the civil servant who pulped the papers to be identified and, if still alive, to give evidence to the inquiry into the deaths of more than 1,700 haemophilia patients exposed to the viruses in contaminated blood. A surviving health department document he found shows officials knew in February 1976 that imported blood products came with a higher hepatitis risk. Rachel Williams Failed recruitment website cost £1.9m The Department of Health admits today that it paid £1.9m to two companies to set up the failed Medical Training Application Service website and in running costs. Patricia Hewitt, then health secretary, said in May that MTAS, under which junior doctors were to apply for specialist training posts, would be shelved as a recruitment system. Hospital Doctor magazine said that Methods Consulting, the IT firm that supplied the website, is working on other NHS IT projects. Last month, the British Medical Association called for an investigation into the true cost of introducing MTAS. Press Association New hearing over death of woman in drug video A fresh inquest into the death of Rachel Whitear, 21, whose body featured in an anti-drugs campaign, will open in Exeter on September 10, it was announced yesterday. A coroner will examine the findings from a reinvestigation of her death after the high court quashed an open verdict recorded at an inquest in December 2000. Miss Whitear was found dead in a bedsit in Exmouth, Devon, in May 2000. Her mother and stepfather, Pauline and Mick Holcroft, of Ledbury, Herefordshire - who allowed images of her body to be used in an anti-drugs video for secondary schools - have long backed calls for a fresh inquest. Press Association Tilda Swinton lined up for Edinburgh film festival The actors Samantha Morton, Tilda Swinton and Bob Hoskins, and directors Stephen Frears and Mike Leigh, will take to the stage during next month's Edinburgh international film festival. Hallam Foe, shot on location in Scotland and starring Billy Elliott actor Jamie Bell, will start the 12-day festival on August 15. The romantic comedy Two Days In Paris, written, directed and starring the French-born US actor Julie Delpy, will close it on August 26. In total 120 feature films from 31 countries will be screened, of which 25 are world or international premieres and 68 will be shown in the UK for the first time. Press Association Photographer assaulted Mills McCartney A photographer was found guilty yesterday of assaulting Heather Mills McCartney in a subway as he tried to take her picture. Jay Kaycappa, 32, grabbed the estranged wife of the former Beatle Paul McCartney by her right shoulder in order to swing her round for a photograph. Brighton magistrates court heard the incident took place in the seaside resort on July 5 last year. Father of three Kaycappa, of Fareham, in Hampshire, who has 132 convictions for dishonesty, was also convicted of assaulting her friend Mark Payne the next evening. Sentencing was adjourned to August 16. Press Association
